? allows the white N to advance.  Perhaps this is harmless, but I see it as an oversight. The position is nearly symmetrical, but with important differences.
Of course.  8. ...0-0 is possible, but for some reason I didn't like that, and played the admittedly passive...
? Loses tempo, hinders a potential 0-0-0.  0-0 seems better, although it felt a bit exposed without the fiancetto bishop.

I thought white was preparing a push at d4, and saw no imminent threat.
My development is complete, white's is lagging.  I am excited about the opposite-castle setup, with both knights prepared to strike at the white king, but I have no plan as of yet.
I didn't see this one coming, but replies were easy to find.

?  Very quiet, this cedes initiative, which white will never fully recover.  White needed to keep the pawn storm coming, finding support for a b5 push (16. c4?), or perhaps offering a sac by pushing immediately: 16. b5 axb5 17. a6 bxa6? 18. Rxa6 and black's king is exposed.

I take the chance to begin my own pawn advance.

I took note of my Rh8, in the line of white's DSB, and in the manner of blitz, blithely ignored the threat...  Here is where I began my attempt to channel my hero, Raoul.  His signature sac is of a minor piece on, in this case, g4, supported by a pawn, with a rook menacing the soon-to-open h file.  I saw that I could achieve this setup and simultaneously support the attacked pawn on e5, and jumped at the opportunity without calculation.
My N reaches the sac square.
With this exchange completed, I can almost feel it coming, but still I don't have a plan.  The best I have seen is the possibility of doubled rooks on an open h file.
With this exchange completed, I can almost feel it coming, but still I don't have a plan.  The best I have seen is the possibility of doubled rooks on an open h file.
There it is!  When white played this, I thought for a while, until I saw a faster attack than doubling the rooks.  Do you see it coming?
!  I offer the sac which I now dub the "Raoul".  In fact, black quickly regains equality, with positional interest, even if white plays accurately.
?  White gobbles the Raoul sac, but this probably loses.  White needed to consider Re1, c4, or activating the Nb1.

There's the open file; the unprotected e2 square is the crucial fact, however.  White needed to play 21. g3 to stay alive, although with 21...Nh3 he will have to give back the N, the K will be on a forced march, and black will be firmly in control.

EDIT:  A chessmaster friend points out this move as a mistake, missing a forced mate:  20...Ne2+  should be played immediately, followed by 21. Kh1 hxg4+ 22. Nh2 Rxh2+ 23. Kxh2 Rh8#
